solution.text:
MRP on the pair of shows\(=\)Rs. \(_{{100*j}}_\)
Discount on the pair of shoes \(=_{k}_\)%
Discount on the pair of shoes in rupees\(=_{k}_\)% \(\times\) MRP
\(=\frac{_{k}_}{100} \times _{{100*j}}_ = \)Rs. \(_{{k*j}}_\)
Sale price of the pair of shoes\(=\)MRP \(-\) Discount
\(=_{{100*j}}_-_{{k*j}}_\)
\(=\)Rs. \(_{{100*j-k*j}}_\)

content.text:
You walk into a store and see that your favourite pair of shoes have an MRP of Rs. \(_{{100*j}}_\).
The sign below them says that they are on sale at a \(_{k}_\)% discount.
How much will you have to pay?
